Author: MetaJames#2985
Content: Interesting topic on crypto security I was wondering about, and maybe some of you also want answers to some of this... So... Do you guys think it's risky to stake multiple coins and download multiple core wallets on a single laptop? Does anyone else do this? What do you guys think are the chances of 'getting hacked one day' or getting attacked by a website or public wifi that was malicious? Could they steal your wallet.dat file and your seed with a keylogger? That's what it would take to jack a core wallet, both of those pieces of information. So, can a hacker ever do this to a fairly savvy crypto staker? It would be interesting to know what you guys think about this topic.

Author: Gordon Komodo#7477
Content: Staking using public WiFi? A hacker can walk by inserted usb drive and keylogger installed in less than few minutes.

Author: Gordon Komodo#7477
Content: Also the owner of the public WiFi can have access to information flowing through the network.

Author: Gordon Komodo#7477
Content: Installing multiple core wallets , if you are sure that all the core wallets are clean then it should be fine.

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: The main issue I think would be being on the same network and exploiting some remote access vulnerability .

Author: nille#9011
Content: good morning everyone ‚òï

Author: PTYX#6840
Content: @MetaJames the more software you have on your laptop the higher the risk. Komodo does security checks of third party coins being added to dpow to prevent vulnerabilities. A keylogger can sit on your machine for months without being noticed. It's important that if you're staking coins, make sure the community is well known and there's credibility. However, it's difficult either way to find if there's a virus or keylogger hidden in a coin daemon.
